correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

body.ab:
refers to page 1.
( ) generation number.
DOZENS OF COUSINS.'
September 1974
How many times have you hoards "I know we're cousins, but how come?"
.Well, back in 1957 I wondered the same thing, so I started investigating the
family history. Several yeats before, Florence McLaughlin Frost had compiled
•the infortfiation but there was only one copy, and some historian along the
way had misplaced it. I started with thtee of.qur ancestors on Page 1 who
were most helpful: Kathtyn McLaughlin Hertdrlck, Catherine Hendrick McLaughlin
and Charles Touhey. From them I received ,the basic outline. The rest was
obtained from many living McLaughlin"'s-"-,and dates on tombstones.'
I set up three duplicate notebooks, arranged: so that pages can be inserted
for many generations to come. Then, we decided to have a printer make up a
booklet. This was distributed in 1958.,, Since then, many nioons and one disastrous
flood have come and gbne. So have most of the booklets! Since there was a great
deal of data to be added, it was suggested .that a new history be OTitten. Now,
after two years of procrastination on my part-—and several years of inflation
on the part of the economy a less expensive -revision is herein presented.
These are Xerox copies and will be easy to duplicate at any time.
That's the story, but, as usual, I'd like ,to add a few personal comments.
First of all, the research was rewarding. L now knew from what branch of the
family tree I had fallen. And I also knew how come the Touhey's, Keenan's et al.
were my cousins.
Secondly, it brings back a smile from my memory bank. I was being "courted"
by James H. Regan at the time and I'm sure he fe^lt that poking around
cemeteries looking for my ancestors 'Was an exciting Saturday afternoon date!
Above all, though, I wish that this younger generation and those to
come---had been as fortunate as I was in knowing almost all the people in this
booklet. The names and dates are here, but the warmth of their personalities
can not be put on paper. The McLaughlin's were industrious, witty, honest,
xTOnderful descendants of Irish inmigrants of the 19th century. They were—and
are--an important part of our American heritage. I'm proud to be one of 'em!
Shirley Frost Regan
DESCE^JDANTS OF JAMES A^^D HANI^IAH MCLAUGHLIN
Natives of County Donegal, Ireland, James (1800-1858) and Hannah (1805-1861)
McLaughlin were parents of eight children. The exact date of their arrival
in the United States is not known.

THE MCLAUGHLIN FAMELY
Origin of family as supplied, "by the Columban Fathers, Silver Creek, N.Y,
MOTTO: ANCHORIS SALUTIS (The Anchor of Salvation)
The Gaelic family name is MacLocglain. It has "been anglicized IfcLaughlin,
MacLoughlin, Loughran, Loughlin and sometimes even Loftus.
The McLaughlin family is desended from Milesius, King of Spain, through
the 5-ine of his son, Heremon. The founder of the family was Fergus Ker'beoil,
son of Conal Crinthine, ancestor of the southern Ny Nials and son of Nial
and the nine hostages who was King of Ireland, A.D. 379• The ancient name
was Lochluin and signifies having spears. The heads of the sept were styled
"by the Princes of Aileach, and their possessions were located in the present
County Donegal.
Ancient Tirowen (Tyrone) was peopled "by the race of Owen, son of Nial and
the nine hostages, and on the introduction of surnames they took the name
of O'Neill (from their ancestor Niall Glundubh, the IJOth monarch of Ireland)
and some of them took the name of McLau^ilin and O'Laughlin from Lochlin,
one of the Kings of Aileach. Some of the McLaughlins during the eleventh
and twelfth centuries were Princes of Tirowen and others of them were monarchs
of Ireland.
One branch, the O'Laughlins, was founded by Fiacha Araidhe, King of Ulster,
in the third century. Their chiefs were styled "Lords of Crei^" and the
possessions of the sept were located in the present Counties of.Clare, Galway
and Donegal.
* Above supplied by l>trs. Gertrude McLaughlin who obtained the information
1 from the Columban Fathers.
